hero.title: Diet & Nutrition: Choosing the Right Food
hero.subtitle: Why I do not recommend domestically produced rat pellets; which commercial diets are relatively trustworthy; and the real value and considerations of the Shunamite Diet mixing system.

body.text: Choosing What to Feed

At the present stage, I do not recommend any form or any brand of domestically produced commercial rat pellets. I sincerely hope that one day a truly trustworthy, well-researched rat-specific diet will emerge in China, but unfortunately, as things stand now, it has not.
Why I Do Not Recommend Domestic Commercial Rat Diets

In today’s pet food market, manufacturers that conduct systematic research specifically focused on the nutritional needs of fancy rats are virtually nonexistent. Even when so-called “nutritional analyses” are provided, they usually remain at a very crude level, such as overall protein or fat percentages.

What is severely lacking is any in-depth breakdown of rat-specific needs, including protein source structure (the balance between animal and plant proteins and specific amino acid requirements), the composition of essential fatty acids, the bioavailability of trace elements and vitamins, and the differing nutritional demands across life stages (juvenile, adult, senior, and breeding).

A more realistic issue lies in production cost structures. Building a dedicated production line solely for fancy rats represents a massive investment. Meanwhile, overall awareness of animal welfare remains limited, and the number of keepers truly willing to invest long-term learning and money into rat nutrition is relatively small. Under such market conditions, few companies are willing to shoulder an investment that is almost guaranteed to lose money.

As a result, what we see in reality is that many so-called “fancy rat pellets” are in fact produced using low-cost cat or dog food production lines, or even outdated formulas that no longer meet basic nutritional standards for cats and dogs.

Such low-cost pellets often fail to meet even baseline feline or canine nutritional requirements, and therefore stand no chance of being suitable for rats—a small mammal with a fast metabolism and a more complex dietary structure.
Are There Any Commercial Diets That Can Be Trusted?
Yes—but very few.

At present, the only commercial diets I recommend are the following well-established, long-validated imported options: Oxbow Essentials Juvenile / Adult Rat Food, Science Selective Rat Food, and Mazuri Rat Diets. Beyond these, I have no additional recommendations.

It should be noted that due to import duties, restrictions, and in some cases gray-market channels, these diets are undeniably expensive. For multi-rat households or ratteries, this often becomes a heavy and ongoing financial burden.
Is There a More Scientific and Cost-Effective Alternative?
Yes—and it is already very mature, provided you are willing to learn and to do the work yourself.

I am referring to the Shunamite Diet mixing philosophy, widely adopted worldwide and developed by Alison Campbell. This is not a simple “recipe,” but a complete, adjustable dietary system that uses behavioral observation as feedback.

Alison systematically compiled years of hands-on experience and interdisciplinary discussion into her book, *The New Scuttling Gourmet*—a 432-page volume that covers nearly all core issues related to fancy rat nutrition.
What Practical Value Does This System Have for You?

It clearly explains how to select ingredients for a mixed diet, how to scientifically categorize them, and what volume ratios to use between categories. It also outlines how nutritional priorities differ across life stages and conditions, how certain behaviors, coat changes, or body condition may indicate specific deficiencies, and even recommends ingredients suitable for a “herbal mix,” allowing rats a degree of self-regulation.

If you have the time, I strongly encourage you to read the original book. It will allow you to adjust ingredients and ratios based on real-world conditions, rather than relying on rigid, experience-based assumptions.
If you do not yet have the energy to study it in depth, you can first learn the essential foundations of mixed feeding through the educational content on my website.

Once you truly understand and master the logic of mixed feeding, even with diverse and high-quality ingredients, you can realistically keep food costs at around 20 RMB per jin. Believe me: in practice, you will find that 20 RMB per jin is already a very high cost for a mixed diet, yet it still remains cheaper than almost all commercial rat pellets on the market while being much closer to an ‘ideal’ dietary state.
Please Do Not Turn the Shunamite Philosophy into a Formula
I have observed a very common—and very dangerous—trend: many people oversimplify Alison’s philosophy into fixed formulas, such as “50% base + XX% protein.” This approach is not advisable.

The core of the Shunamite Diet has never been about rigid ratios. It is a dynamic, adjustable, individual-centered dietary system. Its value lies in allowing you to modify ingredients and proportions according to age, health, activity level, and breeding status, rather than being constrained by formulas that merely look ‘scientific.’
Does Mixed Feeding Have No Drawbacks?

It does have drawbacks—quite a few, in fact—but I consider them acceptable under current circumstances. Unlike commercial pellets, mixed feeding cannot guarantee that every bite contains exactly the same nutrients. Differences in intake speed and food choice between individuals are inevitable.

However, by providing a sufficiently wide variety of ingredients and reducing the weight of any single item in the overall mix, these effects can be almost entirely mitigated. This also lowers the nutritional risks associated with selective eating or food competition: if one ingredient is missed, others can compensate.

More importantly, this approach brings additional benefits. It greatly enhances dietary enrichment, allowing rats to gain exploration and enjoyment from the act of eating itself—an experience that no form of commercial pellet, including compressed ‘block-style’ mixes, can truly provide.

Following Alison’s mixed-feeding approach means preparing a wide range of ingredients: various grains, multiple sources of animal protein, multiple sources of plant protein, and many other miscellaneous components.

These ingredients are often not fully used in a single batch, and their consumption rates differ, creating a risk of spoilage. When you have only a small number of rats and low turnover, I recommend finding a reliable ‘larger group.’
This ‘larger group’ can be a trusted rattery or equally responsible friends. By purchasing and mixing together, ingredients are consumed more quickly, reducing waste.
A Side Note: Mixing Diets Is Hard Work and Requires Responsibility

Preparing mixed diets is labor-intensive, time-consuming, and demands a high level of responsibility. If someone takes on this work on your behalf, they deserve appropriate financial or emotional support. Calculating only ‘ingredient costs’ while ignoring the effort of the person doing the mixing is inherently unfair.
